overview: Ritmo is an interactive app designed to help users learn and practice Latin dance moves through video tutorials and step-by-step guides, complementary to going to live classes.
objectiveGoals: Develop a centralised comprehensive dance move library that is easy to understand for different skill levels
Facilitate easy navigation and search functionality
Incorporate user feedback for continuous improvement
Provide instructions for follower and leads dancers
background: During dance practicas or socials, I frequently encounter leads inquiring about particular moves they're trying to remember and recreate. As a dance instructor, it's essential for me to have access to this library either for guiding my students towards it or utilising it myself. This way, I can provide them with the correct move to reference if they wish to practice it independently.

designProcess.research: As I am around dancers all the time, I conducted semi-informal interviews with a couple of students in the community as well as fellow instructors, who shared their experience with me. I distilled all the goals, needs, and painpoints with respective user personas, and mapped out possible user journey flow charts which inform possible features for MVP or MVP+.
designProcess.definingProblem: Users struggle to find cohesive and organized resources for learning Latin dance moves. Something that came out quite frequently is that there are several different naming conventions, which can mean different moves depending where you are taught. Because the moves are often in Spanish, non-Spanish speakers either mishear the calls or can't remember them, which does not help when they are trying to look them up online.
designProcess.ideation: Brainstormed various features like a video library, save functionality, search bars (and what exactly users can use to look up moves - in this case a descriptive search may be useful aside from keywords). Students and instructors tend to look up moves in class or practicas, so designing mobile-first is an essential approach for it's success.
designProcess.prototyping: Developed wireframes and interactive prototypes using Figma, focusing on userflows, user personas and interface design. At this stage I am focusing on a minimal viable product, which includes the moves library and a profile where users can save their moves for future reference. I have designed the streaks and tracking for a Phase 2 implementation, depending how fast I get the developed.
designProcess.feedback: So far I have shown the wireframes to a few students, who gave really good constructive feedback such as including rueda hand signals and providing several sources of video content to be able to view the move from different angles.

designProcessImages.caption: User personas for a Beginner and Improvers level student
User personas for a Intermediate/Advanced level student, and Dance Instructor
User Journey flowchart for beginner student Sofia
User Journey flowchart for Improvers student Mark
User Journey flowchart for Intermediate/Advanced student Javier
User Journey flowchart for dance instructor Carla

The first three super low fidelity wireframes I created to visualise the main idea for the app - Search functionality to filter the move, dance-style focused page, and a dance-move focus page with all the details. I tend to start from very low-details to get the idea on the page to then gradually adding more and more details. This allows me to keep my focus on the must-have functionality, rather than creating a cluttered interface right of the bat.

solutionImplementation.designDecisions: Prioritised a clean and intuitive UI to enhance user experience and accessibility. Kept functionality to an MVP state for now (the library, user profile and onboarding flow). Whilst the tracking features are really good to have, I found that for the main pain point that being able to look up, read about and save moves is more crucial than trying to track progress. However having features to intiate motivation into the students to keep practising and learning is definitely one of the main factors for long-term sucess of the app.
solutionImplementation.accessibilityUsability: Ensured compliance with WCAG guidelines for improved accessibility. So far this as been established with colour contrast checks, using ARIA labels when developing the app and creating a accessibility-friendly layout. The next step I want to incorporate might be a dark/light UI switch for those who struggle with astigmatism or similar. It would also be good to get the app tested with users who have accessibility needs to see whether the current implementation is actually working for those users.
solutionImplementation.challengesFaced: Overcame initial technical hurdles related to video streaming and user data management. I have to incorporate open-source links via Youtube to get video content currently, as there are lots of moves to cover. The tracking feature I'm currently looking into will require some research and upskilling in particular tech frameworks that can handle this task.

lessonsLearned.designInsights: User feedback is invaluable in the design process; iterate quickly based on real user needs. Was also great to learn about what students are looking for (and fellow instructors), as they tend to voice frustrations every now and then, but it's been helpful to channel those ideas into a possible solutions. Will continue gathering feedback each phase of rolling out changes.
lessonsLearned.technicalInsights: Investing in a solid backend architecture pays off during scaling and feature expansion. I learned that SQLite might be stretched with the amount of moves I might need to documents (for one style it's fine - approx. 200 moves), but any further upscalling may need a more rebust SQL database.
lessonsLearned.improvements: Future updates should focus on enhancing personalisation and supporting students on their own journeys - each student has a different background and a different reason to why they started dance classes. It's important to support those needs on a equity-based lens, rather than creating a universal solution that is trying to 'fit all' but may miss certain students.

keyTakeaways.summary: Ritmo so far successfully combines a straight-forward, simple design with robust functionality to create a valuable resource for Latin dance enthusiasts. However, as it is still in its infancy, there is still lots of potential and scope to explore that makes this app even more useful to the latin dance community.
keyTakeaways.demonstrationSkills: Showcased skills in UX design, full stack development, and user-centered research. Incorporating regular testing session with local students. Exploring dark UI design and improve auto-layout skills for mobile.

overview: Optimal Workshop Templates is a collection of pre-built templates designed to streamline the user research and information architecture processes. The MVP product aims to educate users on best practices while accelerating setup times for both novice and experienced users of Optimal Workshop's tools.
objectiveGoals: Create pre-built templates that demonstrate best practices in user research and information architecture.
Enhance user learning by providing well-documented templates that guide users through effective techniques.
Speed up the setup process for experienced users by offering customisable templates that reduce the need for manual configuration.
Ensure templates are versatile and can be adapted to various project needs, from simple to complex.
background: The Templates project was initiated to address the need for structured and educational resources within Optimal Workshop's suite of tools. The goal was to make it easier for users to apply best practices in their research and design workflows, thus improving overall efficiency and effectiveness. Additionally it addressed the initial 'blank screen' scenario, where less experienced users may find themselves in, unsure where to start especially if they had a specific research outcome in mind.

designProcess.research: Conducted user interviews and surveys to identify common challenges and needs in user research and information architecture. Analysed existing tools and templates for gaps and opportunities. Conducted competitor analysis to highlight gaps in the market.
designProcess.definingProblem: Inexperienced users needed more guidance when setting up research projects, as they often found themselves unsure how to connect the tools with the results they were hoping to achieve. Experienced users needed a way to quickly start projects with structured templates that would also serve as educational tools to enable them to explore the tools in ways they may have not thought of. Often they would recommend certain tools and processes around it to the juniors in their teams. The challenge was to design templates that were both instructive and adaptable.
designProcess.ideation: Brainstormed various template formats and structures. Considered including step-by-step guides, examples of best practices, and customisable elements for different use cases. Pre-filled fields inside the tools to allow users to get an impression of how they could shape their data.
designProcess.prototyping: Developed initial prototypes of templates using design tools like Figma. Created an MVP, which we then A/B tested with a small user group.
designProcess.feedback: Gathered feedback from both novice and experienced users after we rolled out the feature to more users to gain feedback. Identified areas for improvement, such as adding more detailed instructions and improving template flexibility.

designProcessImages.caption: This user journey shows the user interaction points where users would creating studies from - dashboard and studies tab. From here, the user can chose a template, which opens up a view with further information on how the template should be used and what it contains.
A simplified view of the user journey.
Preview of the medium-fidelity wireframes for the templates feature.

solutionImplementation.designDecisions: Focused on creating clear, structured templates with instructional content to guide users. Prioritised ease of use and adaptability in design decisions.
solutionImplementation.testing: Performed extensive usability testing with different user groups. Evaluated the effectiveness of templates in improving user understanding and setup efficiency.
solutionImplementation.challengesFaced: Faced challenges in balancing template complexity with ease of use. Had to iterate on design to meet diverse user needs while maintaining simplicity.

lessonsLearned.designInsights: Learned the importance of clear documentation and user guidance within templates. Found that simplicity in design often leads to better user adoption and satisfaction. However it is important to remember, that this feature is only a piece in the bigger puzzle of customer onboarding and retention.
lessonsLearned.technicalInsights: Allowed me to further learn and analyse the exisiting tools in the product better. Gained experience in integrating templates with existing tools. Improved skills in creating adaptable, modular designs.
lessonsLearned.improvements: Future improvements could include more advanced customisation options and enhanced instructional content to further support users in learning best practices.

keyTakeaways.summary: The Optimal Workshop Templates project successfully created a set of pre-built templates that facilitate user research and information architecture while serving as educational tools. It highlighted the value of combining instructional content with practical tools. The next step involves expanding the range of use cases by introducing additional templates. This will provide users with pre-configured data across various areas of the tool, enhancing their ability to seamlessly integrate and transfer information between different tools.
keyTakeaways.demonstrationSkills: Demonstrated skills in product design, user research, and integration with existing tools. Showcased ability to design for both usability and instructional purposes.

overview: The Ministry of Education Design System was developed to address the need for a consistent, accessible, and efficient design framework following the rapid creation of a website during the COVID-19 lockdown. This design system includes a comprehensive component library and design guidelines aimed at ensuring uniformity and adherence to accessibility standards across digital platforms.
objectiveGoals: Create a unified design system to ensure consistency across web platforms for the Ministry of Education.
Develop a component library that includes the most commonly used design elements, adhering to accessibility and usability standards.
Provide clear design guidelines and documentation to support future development and maintenance.
Facilitate quicker and more efficient website development by offering reusable components and standardized design patterns.
background: In response to the urgent need to build a functional and consistent website during the COVID-19 lockdown ('Learning from Home'), the Ministry of Education recognised the necessity for a robust design system. The design system was conceived to streamline future development efforts and enhance the overall user experience across digital touchpoints.

designProcess.research: Conducted a comprehensive analysis of existing design systems and component libraries. Reviewed feedback from the rapid website development project to identify pain points and areas for improvement. Held extensive interviews and workshops with stakeholders (which consistent of members of the IT teams such as developers, business analysts, content developers, web advisors, ux designers and more). Part of this workshop was to create buy-in for a design system solution, whilst also figuring out the goals, needs and pain-points of each stakeholder. I took a co-design approach, where I developed a strategy together with the lead engineer of the team, who consulted the project with technical input.
designProcess.definingProblem: The lack of a standardised design framework led to inconsistencies and inefficiencies in the rapid development of the website. This became clear once the web team had to quickly produce the 'Learning from Home' website in response to the COVID-19 lockdown in 2020. The lack of a unified design system meant that coming up with a design, and building it was a lot slower than we could afford (the project retrospective highlighted several crucial painpoints, all relating back to slow turnover and low confidence on development and design decisions). The primary challenge was to create a design system that addressed these issues while meeting accessibility requirements.
designProcess.ideation: Developed initial concepts for the design system, including core components, design patterns, and guidelines. Decided on a website solution, due to the regular engagement with third-party vendors, who needed the guidance and inspiration of exisiting sites (displayed as 'Case Studies'). Therefore a website was a reasonable approach, compared to keeping the information on an internal platform. Engaged with stakeholders to gather input on essential features and requirements as the wireframes took shape. As we worked on other projects, essential components and patterns were agreed on and defined in smaller feedback loops.
designProcess.prototyping: Created prototypes of key components and design patterns using Adobe XD. Tested prototypes with internal teams to validate functionality and gather feedback. Whilst the site was built, we utilised Confluence as an interim solution to build out the content for the guidance pages.
designProcess.feedback: Incorporated feedback from designers, developers, and accessibility experts. Adjusted the design system based on usability testing and stakeholder input to ensure it met diverse needs and standards.

designProcessImages.caption: First I started by doing a bit of secondary research into exisiting design systems, especially in government and education space sector. I would audit them and figure out commonalities, as well as informing myself on specific features that are useful to use when creating a medium that contains all the guidance information about components and patterns.

In order to create a site that had useful information, I had to create a sitemap which helped organize and structure the content in a logical way. Because several different teams were going to use this (Developers, UX Designers, Brand designers, Content Developers, Web Advisors, etc.), the information architecture had to be clear but able to grow as the design system became more evolved.

Developed low-fidelity wireframes, which enabled me to figure out the structure and hierarchy of content. That way I was able to determine some of our earliest components that we were going to publish in the design system, such as headers, button, footers and cards.

From there on I started to give the wireframes more detail. This happened along-side an iterative process with the teams, who gave me feedback around what information they would need to effectively write, develop or design solutions. This means the content was able to be shaped before I implemented any UI Design and Branding onto the site.

solutionImplementation.designDecisions: Focused on creating a design system that emphasised consistency, accessibility, and ease of use. Prioritised the development of reusable components that could be easily customised.
solutionImplementation.accessibilityUsability: Ensured compliance with WCAG 2.1 guidelines to make the design system inclusive. Included features like keyboard navigation and screen reader support in component designs.
solutionImplementation.challengesFaced: Encountered challenges in ensuring the design system met all accessibility standards and was adaptable to various use cases. Addressed these by incorporating detailed guidelines and extensive testing.

lessonsLearned.designInsights: Learned the importance of creating a design system that balances flexibility with consistency. Discovered that clear documentation and thorough testing are critical for successful implementation. Design systems only work if everyone is using it (so the buy-in process at the start with the workshop was more important than originally thought!). There also needs to be a solid process and criteria in place, there are right and wrong ways to document and good planning helps in the long run.
lessonsLearned.technicalInsights: Gained experience in integrating a design system with existing digital platforms and managing version control for a shared component library. Improved skills in developing accessible and reusable components.
lessonsLearned.improvements: Future iterations of the design system could benefit from enhanced documentation, more detailed usage examples, and expanded support for additional design patterns and components. Also planned to include case studies, to show how the design system could be utilised, and highlighting why design systems are so useful for cross-collaborative teams.

keyTakeaways.summary: The Ministry of Education Design System successfully provided a standardised approach to design and development, improving consistency and efficiency in digital projects. It highlighted the value of having a comprehensive design system to support future needs.
keyTakeaways.demonstrationSkills: Demonstrated skills in UX/UI design, component library creation, accessibility compliance, and technical leadership. Showcased ability to develop and implement a design system from conception to deployment.

overview: The NCEA Website project aimed to provide teachers with a centralised platform to access information on new assessment standards, subject materials, and updates on the change programme. The project involved designing a user-friendly interface that simplifies navigation and enhances access to crucial educational resources.
objectiveGoals: Create an intuitive platform for teachers to access up-to-date information on NCEA assessment standards and subject materials.
Improve the user experience by offering streamlined navigation and easy access to essential resources.
Ensure that the platform supports educators in understanding and implementing changes in the NCEA assessment programme.
Incorporate feedback from educators to continuously refine and enhance the website's functionality and content.
background: The NCEA Website was developed in response to the NCEA Change Programme, which kicked off in 2019. This was the first step to digitise and create a single touch point for teachers to access the newly updated assessment standards, newly introduced subjects and materials.

designProcess.research: Conducted user research through interviews and surveys with teachers to understand their needs and pain points. Most of the insights were received though the change programme workstreams itself, as the advisors worked closely with the teachers. Analysed existing systems and best practices for educational websites.
designProcess.definingProblem: Identified key problems including fragmented information, difficult navigation, and outdated content. Defined the need for a unified platform to streamline access to NCEA resources. This was often done by reviewing proposed changes to the ncea programme, in form of a workshop with the advisors.
designProcess.ideation: Brainstormed design solutions that included user-friendly navigation, clear categorisation of resources, and a responsive design. Created wireframes and user flows to visualise the proposed solution.
designProcess.prototyping: Developed interactive prototypes using tools like Adobe XD. Conducted usability testing with teachers to gather feedback and refine the design.
designProcess.feedback: Collected feedback from initial user testing and stakeholder reviews. Incorporated suggestions to improve the usability and effectiveness of the design. Because the designs were worked on in parallel to the change programme itself, stakeholders and teachers who worked at the Ministry provided regular feedback. Regular consulation periods were held with NCEA teachers who worked at New Zealand schools.

solutionImplementation.designDecisions: Focused on creating a clean and intuitive interface to facilitate easy access to information. Prioritised responsive design to ensure accessibility across devices.
solutionImplementation.accessibilityUsability: Ensured compliance with WCAG 2.1 guidelines to make the website accessible to all users. Included features such as keyboard navigation and screen reader support.
solutionImplementation.challengesFaced: Faced challenges in the design process overall, as it was Waterfall based, and often the designs proceeded the content production, which created blue-sky scenarios. The user consulations were not consistent, so we had stages where we had no validation around whether the designs meet the users needs. Incorporating different cultural world views was tricky, as we had limited access to certain demographic groups.

lessonsLearned.designInsights: Learned the importance of designing for diverse user needs and incorporating feedback early in the design process. Discovered the value of a modular design for future scalability.
lessonsLearned.improvements: Future iterations could include more interactive features and enhanced personalisation options for users. Continued user feedback will be crucial for ongoing improvements.

keyTakeaways.summary: The NCEA Website project successfully delivered a centralised platform for teachers, improving access to crucial educational resources and streamlining navigation. The project highlighted the importance of user-centered design and effective integration of educational content.
keyTakeaways.demonstrationSkills: Showcased skills in UX/UI design, technical leadership, and user testing. Demonstrated ability to deliver a high-quality, scalable solution for educational needs. This project allowed me to grow from an intermediate designer into a Senior UX/UI Designer by taking on more responsibility.
